Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I was just settling in for a quiet evening when my phone rang. It was Sam, frantic and nearly in tears, convinced he’d left his passport at home on his way to the airport. He begged me to check his apartment and, if I found it, rush it to him before his flight. As his friend, I knew how much this trip meant to him, and I couldn’t imagine letting him down in such a crucial moment. I grabbed my keys, ready to dash out the door.

But just then, the city’s emergency alert blared through my phone and the building’s alarms. A flash-flood warning. Water was already pooling outside, and the authorities urged everyone to stay indoors and avoid the streets for our own safety and to keep roads clear for emergency vehicles. As a responsible citizen, I knew I should follow these instructions, not only for my own safety but for the well-being of the whole community.

Standing in my hallway, keys in hand, I felt torn in two. My loyalty to Sam pulled me one way, while my duty to my neighbors and city pulled me another. My heart pounded as I weighed the risks and responsibilities, caught between being a good friend and a responsible citizen.
